titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Reginald Horace Blyth papers, 1948-1970 RL.11762

publicationstmt.publisher: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2019-09-26 14:10:45 UTC.

repository.corpname: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

did.abstract: Reginald Horace Blyth popularized Japanese poetic forms such as haiku and senryū within English-speaking audiences by publishing insightful, widely read English translations. Born in Essex, England, Blyth studied literature and went to Korea in 1925 to teach at the newly established Imperial University in Keijo (present-day Seoul) and moved to Japan in 1940. During WWII, he was interned in a Japanese camp as a noncombatant alien. After the war, Blyth served as an intermediary between American Occupation leaders and the Japanese. Notably, Blyth helped draft the Ningen Sengen declaration, which stated that Emperor Hirohito was a human being and not divine. Blyth also served throughout the post-war era as a tutor to Crown Prince Akihito. In addition, Blyth was an associate of Zen teacher D.T. Suzuki and other Buddhist practitioners and authors who, along with him, introduced Zen to Western audiences. Blyth's own books include Zen in English Literature and Oriental Classics, the series Zen and Zen Classics, Senryu: Japanese Satirical Verses, and Oriental Humor. The collection includes manuscript drafts, notes, and notebooks for published and unpublished works. Many of the files relate to his books on Japanese poetry, humor, and Zen, as well as to his works about British and American Literature. Other files relate to unpublished works and to research interests about animism, culture and mysticism, the British poet John Clare, language, love, and satanism. The bulk of the Printed Materials series includes an incomplete selection of Blyth's published books as well as newsletters and commentary from the Diamond Sangha in Honolulu.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into the following series: Correspondence, Writings and Research, and Printed Materials. With few exceptions, Japanese names in this collection guide have been written following Western naming conventions, with the given name first and family name last.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Reginald Horace Blyth popularized Japanese poetic forms such as haiku and senryū within English-speaking audiences by publishing insightful, widely read English translations. Born in Essex, England, Blyth studied literature and went to Korea in 1925 to teach at the newly established Imperial University in Keijo (present-day Seoul) and moved to Japan in 1940. During WWII, he was interned in a Japanese camp as a noncombatant alien. After the war, Blyth served as an intermediary between American Occupation leaders and the Japanese. Notably, Blyth helped draft the Ningen Sengen declaration, which stated that Emperor Hirohito was a human being and not divine. Blyth also served throughout the post-war era as a tutor to Crown Prince Akihito. In addition, Blyth was an associate of Zen teacher D.T. Suzuki and other Buddhist practitioners and authors who along with him introduced Zen to Western audiences. Blyth's own books include Zen in English Literature and Oriental Classics, the series Zen and Zen Classics, Senryu: Japanese Satirical Verses, and Oriental Humor. The bulk of Blyth's work was first published between 1942 and 1963. Blyth died in Tokyo in 1964.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: The donor asserts copyright interest in this collection. Contact Rubenstein Library Research Services regarding publication permissions.

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: The Reginald Horace Blyth papers were received by the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library as a purchase in 2019.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Reginald Horace Blyth papers, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Accessions described in this collection guide: 2019-0082.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Researchers may also be interested in the Norman Waddell papers, 1986-2008, and the Philip Kapleau papers, 1952-2004.

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: Manuscript drafts, notes, and notebooks for published and unpublished works by Reginald Horace Blyth. Many of the files relate to his books on Japanese poetry, humor, and Zen, as well as his works about British and American Literature. Some materials are written in Japanese. Of note, there are 20 folders of notebooks about senryū poetry, which are written in Japanese and translated into English with explication. Other files relate to unpublished works and research interests about animism, culture and mysticism, the British poet John Clare, language, love, and satanism. The bulk of the Printed Materials series includes an incomplete selection of Blyth's published books as well as newsletters and commentary from the Diamond Sangha in Honolulu.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: One letter about Mu, Zen, and poetry

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Manuscript drafts, notes, and notebooks for published and unpublished works by Blyth. Arranged alphabetically by subject. Many of the files relate to his books on Japanese poetry, humor, and Zen, as well as to his works about British and American Literature. Some materials are written in Japanese. Of note, there are 20 folders of notebooks about senryū poetry, which are written in Japanese and translated into English with explication. It appears that there were a few contributors to the notebooks other than Blyth; these included Toshiko Chiba and Laura Rill. Blyth mentions Toshiko Chiba in the prefaces to several of his books. There are also some haiku translations by Akiko Kobayashi. Other files relate to unpublished works and to research interests about animism, culture and mysticism, the British poet John Clare, language, love, and satanism. Almost none of the files have dates, but they were likely created between 1948 and 1964.

did.unittitle: Christianity and Buddhism typed manuscript draft
Formative Reading Experiences of Children manuscript draft
Haiku chosen and written out by Kobayashi Akiko
Toshiko Chiba notebooks of haiku and senryū with English translations
Japanese riddles, songs, puns, and proverbs
Miscellaneous notes on literature, the tragic-comic, and Zen
Senryū and Haiku introduction manuscript draft

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Some of the notebooks appear to have several contributors. The names of Laura Rill and Toshiko Chiba are inscribed on the front of many of the notebooks, suggesting that they provided translations to Blyth. The notebooks are in Japanese and English and show edits and notes. There are 20 folders in all, and each folder contains several notebooks.

did.unittitle: Zen and Zen Classics Vol. III
Zen and Zen Classics Vol. III
Zen and Zen Classics Vol. III

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Arranged into two subseries: Printed Books by Blyth and Printed Materials by Others.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: An incomplete selection of Blyth's published books on British and American literature, Buddhism, humor, Korean language, and Japanese poetry. Some books include ownership inscriptions by Norman Waddell and "Akiko." Akiko may refer to Blyth's secretary Akiko Kobayashi, who provided translations to Blyth. Norman Waddell is a scholar of Japanese Zen Buddhism. Some of the books were used for instruction by Blyth and include minimal marginalia. The books are arranged chronologically by the date that each title was first published.
